The Chairperson will award grants to nonprofit educational institutions to establish Presidential Academies for Teaching of American History and Civics. These Academies will offer workshops for teachers to improve their teaching of American history and civics and enhance their knowledge of these subjects. Nonprofit educational institutions must submit an application to receive a grant, containing required information as specified by the Chairperson. The Chairperson will award grants to nonprofit educational institutions to establish Presidential Academies for Teaching of American History and Civics. The application must include criteria for teacher selection, the primary professor, and curriculum details. A maximum of 12 grants will be awarded, ensuring equitable distribution. The Chairperson ensures equitable distribution of grants among US regions. Grants are for a 2-year term, renewable for one more term or a new grant can be awarded. Nonprofit educational institutions receiving grants must establish an Academy offering a 2-week workshop for K-12 teachers to enhance their teaching of American history and civics. Each Academy is led by a primary professor. Each Academy, headed by a primary professor, must select 300 K-12 teachers annually to attend a workshop on American history and civics. The primary professor designs the curriculum and appoints core teachers to assist in teaching the workshop attendees. The Academy selects teachers from public and private schools to attend workshops on American history and civics. The number of teachers chosen can vary based on the region's population, with a focus on teachers from the same region as the Academy. Teachers attending workshops under this section will not incur costs except for travel expenses, which must be covered using non-Federal funds. An evaluation will be conducted to assess the grant program's success and identify best practices for future grantees.
